title: Airport taxis charge same for now
text:
Airport taxis charge same for now 2 Jul 2015 at 03:29 193 viewed 0   LIFE | WRITER: KARNJANA KARNJANATAWE 
Passengers still pay 50 baht for taxi surcharge at Survarnabhumi airport. - + Taxi surcharge at Suvarnabhumi and Don Mueang airports remains the same at 50 baht, according to the Transport Minister Prajin Juntong. 
The flat rate has not yet been increased as proposed by the Transport Ministry committee in May and supported by the minister as widely reported by media last month. The committee suggested the new surcharge rates rise to 75 baht for saloon taxis and 95 baht for larger taxi vans while the minister wanted the rate to be a bit lower, perhaps to 60 baht and 80 baht respectively. 
However, the final decision has not yet been made. 
"The 50 baht surcharge will not be changed, neither will there be a discussion about a subsidised budget to absorb the hike for passengers," he said. Flights 'personalised' by 2018 
Personalised services through mobile devices will be the focus of airlines over the next three years, according to the latest survey of SITA 2015 Airline IT Trends. 
The survey was conducted in association with Airline Business magazine early this year by sending questionnaires to a senior IT executive in each of the top 200 passenger carriers. 
It found that only 20% of airlines offered services that are personalised for individual passengers. But the number will increase in the next three years when 82% of airlines will address the issue by tailoring their services to fit each passenger's need at the airport and during their flight. 
The services will not be limited to flight discovery function, but also information updates relating to baggage and customer service that can resolve travel problems. 
At the airport, kiosks and beacons will also play a part in delivering a personalised journey. Passengers, for instance, will be able to download content for the flight including books and films from media kiosks to their tablets or smartphones. About 22% of airlines are expecting to offer this service by 2018. 
The survey also predicted that those personalised services will be available through smartphones, tablet and social media. 
In terms of wearable technology, the survey found that only 7% of airlines have so far looked at its potential while the majority of airlines are still waiting to see how others will implement this technology. Airlines update AirAsia will launch four weekly flights between Bangkok and the Malaysian southern hub Johor Baharu on July 17. 
"Travel demand between Thailand and Malaysia is growing fast every year. Just last year alone we have carried over 2 million guests between the two countries," said AirAsia Berhad Head of Commercial Spencer Lee. 
The unique new route from Bangkok to Johor Baharu will further stimulate travel demands between the two cities and boost tourism growth for the region, he added. Johor Baharu is the state capital of Johor located at the southernmost part of Malaysia. It houses the first Sanrio Hello Kitty town outside of Japan at Nusajaya, with shopping outlets and historical attractions such as the Johor royal family's principal palace Istana Besar, or Grand Palace. 
Flights will depart from Don Mueang airport at 8.45pm and the departure time from Johor Baharu's Senai International Airport is at 6.55pm. Visit www.airasia.com for more details. Etihad Airways launched its fourth daily service between Abu Dhabi and Bangkok yesterday. 
Operated by a B777-300ER aircraft, the new service will increase the number of round-trip flights which Etihad Airways operates between the two cities to 28 per week, adding approximately 5,000 weekly seats to the route. 
It will also increase capacity for guests connecting to the Bangkok service from other points on Etihad Airways' global network and from flights to Abu Dhabi operated by its partner airlines, according to Etihad Airways Chief Strategy and Planning Officer Kevin Knight. 
The new flight departs from Suvarnabhumi airport at 6.20pm and the return trip from Abu Dhabi airport is at 11.30pm. Visit www.etihad.com for more details. Hotels update The Dusit Thani Krabi Beach Resort was launched yesterday. 
The 240-room property, formerly known as the Sheraton Krabi Beach Resort, is owned by MBK Group. 
It is located on Klong Muang Beach and is about 30km from Krabi airport. 
"Rebranding under the Dusit Thani label means the resort now fully embodies the beauty of being Thai,'" said resort owner, president and CEO of MBK Group Suvait Theeravachirakul. 
The hotel offers seven types of rooms with space usage starting from 46m² for the deluxe room type to 150m² for a suite with a plunge pool. Also offered are three restaurants, a bar, two beachfront swimming pools, meeting facilities, spa, fitness, club lounge and a kids' club. Visit www.dusitthanikrabi.com for more details. Six Senses Samui reopened yesterday. 
After completing renovations, "the resort is now brighter and offers a more spacious feel and functionality", said resort GM Gary Henden. 
The resort offers 59 villas with space usage starting from 130m² to 300m². It added new plunge pools to some villas and upgraded its main infinity pool with new decking, furniture and landscape. Other facilities also include a lighter tone, making the resort look more modernised. 
"I am delighted to see the evolution of Six Senses Samui. The revitalised product and enhanced services lift our resort to new heights on the island," added Henden.
